newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico stocks end down, take a break from records.
newsitem.headline: Mexico stocks end down, take a break from records.

text.p: Mexican stocks ended off on Friday in what traders and analysts said was a breather after chalking up three record closes in a row.

"It was just profit-taking after it hit 4,000 points again. The market looks firm, although it ought to capitalize gains better at brisker volume," said Roberto Campuzano, an analyst at the Invex brokerage in Mexico City.

The leading IPC share index ended down 11.23 points, or 0.28 percent, at 3,988.29. The IPC had climbed as high as a new intraday record of 4,013.99 points in early trade. Trading volume was lacklustre at 59.6 million shares.
Some dealers said light profit-taking was due to U.S. brokers closing their books ahead of the Memorial Day holiday, for which U.S. financial markets will close on Monday, May 26.
"As Wall Street closes on Monday, several dealers decided to go into the long weekend either flat or with cash in hand. But locals did step in a little to buy low," one trader said.
The Dow Jones meanwhile soared 87.78 points to 7,345.91 points.
The IPC closely shadowed the changing fortunes of Telmex stock, which ended off two centavos at 17.42 pesos, down from a session high of 17.52 pesos.
The telecomms' ADRs similarly ended off 1/8 at 44-1/4, but had traded earlier at 44-5/8.

Telmex was unseated form its usual first place on the most-traded stocks list by builder Consorcio Hogar, which made an initial public offering on Friday. Hogar closed the session at its issue price of 10.40 pesos.
On the broad market, 106 shares traded hands, of which sliders outpaced gainers by 53 to 34.
